awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Turbulence and Dynamics of Stars
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support a two-pronged attack on the problems of understanding supernova progenitors and of the physics of supernovae up to and immediately after the explosion.  The first project, to be led by Dr. Arnett of the University of Arizona, will model the late evolutionary phase preceding iron core collapse (Type II supernovae) in massive stars.  This will be the first time that such calculations have been done in three spatial dimensions, and will cover evolution to the onset of core collapse including an evaluation of the role played by rotation and other mechanisms of symmetry breaking.  This epoch is characterized by a complex interplay between turbulence and nuclear burning that determines the entropy and density structure of the pre-collapse core, which along with rotation are important characteristics in determining the outcome of the core-collapse event.  The second effort, led by Dr. Starrfield of Arizona State University, will explore accretion onto white dwarfs using compositions ranging from pure helium to a mixture with varying abundances of heavy elements.  The goal of this work is to determine the initial conditions that lead either to a Supernova Type Ia explosion, an energetic helium flash, or helium novae.  This work is motivated by the inconvenient situation that the kind of star producing Type Ia supernovae is still unknown, and both theoretical and observational arguments for and against various scenarios have only grown more complicated in recent years. Common to both projects is a numerical code that includes a new theory of turbulent convection in three-dimensions that includes good resolution in both spatial dimensions and in time. 

The project is expected to impact the wider astrophysical community through the release of stellar evolution and convection codes.  The project will also support the training of students and a postdoctoral fellow, and the results of this work will be incorporated into the curricula at both institutions.

por.por_cntn:
Final Outcomes Report for 1107445, Collaborative Research: Turbulence and Dynamics of Stars

In 1949, J. von Neumann wrote a report to the Office of Naval Research in which he summarized research on the theory of turbulence, and suggested that ``extensive, but well-planned computational efforts" might able to ``break the deadlock" on this thorny problem. In the subsequent 66 years, Moore's law has been approximately followed by computer technology, and the immense increase in computing power now allows simulations, in three dimensions, of fluid flow with sufficient resolution to exhibit fully developed turbulence. Stars are plasma of high energy density, and therefore behave as gravitationally stratified, potentially turbulent fluids. Their evolution is strongly affected by the combination of turbulent mixing (which smooths composition gradients) and thermonuclear burning (which generates such gradients).

We have demonstrated the validity of von Neumann's insight by simulating turbulent convection on supercomputers in the U.S., Australia, and England, with the help of an informal group of collaborators in each of the countries. We have then extensively analyzed the Pentabyte of data from multiple numerical experiments to obtain an understanding and concise theoretical representations of this data.  

Our goal is to better understand how stars evolve. To apply this new insight into the behavior of turbulent convection in stars requires another step. Because the time for a star to evolve is much longer than the time for a turbulent zone to mix, we must encapsulate the long term behavior of turbulence into computer codes for stellar evolution. This requires that we average over the chaotic behavior of turbulence to obtain its average behavior. The problem is analogous to weather prediction (our simulations) and climate prediction (stellar evolution). In addition, because stars are very nearly spherically symmetric (on average), we project our three-dimensional theory onto a spherical (one-dimensional) grid, for use in stellar evolution codes. This we call ``321D'', a term coined by our collaborator John Lattanzio.

The 321D algorithm has passed preliminary tests, and is now being implemented in stellar evolution codes, beginning with the open-source community code MESA. Due to the rapid increase in observational information, from asteroseismology and better ground-based and space-based instruments, there are a wealth of new problems which illustrate the limitations of our previous ideas of stellar evolution. Among the most spectacular are related to the approach to core collapse in massive stars, the supernova explosion, the formation and ejection of most of the chemical elements, and the origin of neutron stars and black holes. Further, a more reliable theory of stellar evolution  is needed to correctly decipher galactic and cosmic history.

Modified by: William D Arnett
